abstracts.cdata!:
The project was satisfactory, with a
            likely sustainability, and substantial institutional
            development impacts. Lessons address the importance of
            borrower ownership, and commitment, objectives which were
            achieved successfully under this project, due to the
            Tanzanian initiative, driven by national individuals with
            strong personal incentives, committed to organizational
            performance as the key to development progress. And, their
            direction during appraisal, and implementation provided the
            ingredients to develop strong ownership, in a less intrusive
            policy agenda, allowing the Bank a more proactive role.
            Despite the choice for a supply-driven approach to
            organizational development, it was this approach which made
            significant contributions in strengthening implementing
            organizations, particularly on financial aspects. Moreover,
            the dynamic drive to modernization, based on Tanzanian
            roots, - and independent of the project - appears to have
            energized the process into which the project evolved. The
            progress of this project provides useful insights,
            particularly when uncertainty conditions prevail, for
            although the unconventional approach given to implementing
            organizations came first, it allowed the broader strategic
            issues, be sorted at an appropriate pace, where analysis had
            to be combined with consensus building, complex learning,
            and legitimization. Nonetheless, more efforts must be made
            at appraisal to build project implementation capacity.
